column1: On 12 May 2021, will Ethiopia's Tigray region be under a federally-imposed state of emergency?
column6: ['Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
Be interesting to see how this resolves and what happens in the coming weeks..

By far the most dubious crowd forecast I've seen. A 0% is more reasonable than a 100% regardless if this turns out yes, in my opinion. The logical assumption seems to be that the SoE is expired. There is incentive to renew but time and chances have elapsed so the evidence to renew is low.

My initial rational was that the fighting was likely to go beyond this six month mark and the situation would not resolve within this period and so some sort of state of emergency (SOE) would stay in place. Looking at things now, I think this question has been poorly thought through by GJO, since it is one where the end result will be some dull technicality.
Given the stat of many African nations descending into chaos (Nigeria, Somalia, DRC, Mozambique) the Ethiopian Government may use this as motivation to leverage an extension of the stat of emergency.
Guess we need to check what happens tomorrow as well

Forgot to change previous forecast. . . . Okay at this point, they have 2 days to make a new one that "extends" the crisis, publicly reveal they renewed one, or something major/new to come up that forces them to create a new one. All these to me do not seem very likely. To me it feels like more than 1 in 100 and less than 1 in 20. However, I will join @jleibowich's forecast so as not to stray from from his, @Ryan-Beck's, and @fisherdbus' forecast.
No news of this that I've heard and the deadline has passed.

There is still a chance to gather a new one. There is a lot of "potential energy" for that since it just expired and they could be working on gathering a new meeting soon to make a new one; the fighting in the city does not seem resolved yet (based on a digital forensic team I saw on Twitter) so I do not understand why they would lift the state of emergency or let it expire. Nonetheless, being faithful to the evidence and not the narrative in this particular case.
OK, so I'll have to revise completely...

Art.93 of the constitution is pretty clear: "A state of emergency decreed by the Council of Ministers, if approved by the House of Peoples’ Representatives, can remain in effect up to six months. The House of Peoples’ Representatives may, by a two-thirds majority vote, allow the state of emergency proclamation to be renewed every four months successively."

The reason (Art.93(1)a "...a break down of law and order which endangers the Constitutional order and which cannot be controlled by the regular law enforcement ") for the assignment of the extra-constitutional powers to the federal government (Art.93(4)a "...have all necessary power to protect the country's peace and sovereignty, and to maintain public security, law and order.") has not been removed yet.

Reading through other posts and research on this topic leads me to think this will continue to be in place. There is a small chance that it is lifted for some reason, but the 6 month initial period is over and the state of emergency has not been lifted or really discussed much.

This is pushing it for evidence, but previously states of emergency have been actively lifted rather than lapsed, and the UK FCO says it's still in-place: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ethiopia and the State of Emergency Inquiry Board hasn't reported since December.
Eritrea has agreed to start withdrawal. This is one of the important steps towards normalization as I noted in my first note. https://reports.unocha.org/en/country/ethiopia/.

I still haven't seen news of it being renewed yet, has anyone else? According to this link it was approved November 5th, so I would think that means it has to be renewed today or it will expire right?

Given current state of violence and extreme conflict in the region, it will be a shock if state of emergency is lifted by May 12.

However, they have issued a new State of Emergency in the Amhara region south of Tigray. I hear there is no evidence that forces have left Tigray.
That crisis in not improving.

Following factors that announce the normalcy has not occurred: 1. Eritrean forces have not withdrawn 2. Elections are planned to happen in June - whether in Tigray, not clear. EU has already committed to send election observers. 3. Intermediation ( representative from EU, the Finnish Foreign Minister's two visit has not yielded any result)

There's some level of denial of the problem, when Commissioner Mitiku Kassa stated recently that "not a single person in Tigray is dying of hunger", and quashed the information and reports from the region as "rumors" with the intention to make Ethiopia look bad. https://www.geeskaafrika.com/ethiopia-no-one-dies-from-hunger-in-tigray/
On 12 May 2022 ,too...
The Declaration was made Nov 4 and goes for 6 months. May 12th is beyond that and would need to be extended.

The Tigray conflict in Ethiopia shows no sign of ending. President Abiy has now admitted that rather than defeat the TPLF, the latter has now regrouped into a guerrilla force led my former high-ranking officers that cannot be overcome within the next three months. This suggests a continuance of the state of emergency.
Only a little over a month left.

Quite a few signs for an extension of the federally-imposed state of emergency: /"We, the G7 Foreign Ministers of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States of America and the High Representative of the European Union are strongly concerned about recent reports on human rights violations and abuses, and violations of international humanitarian law in Tigray." https://www.gov.uk/government/news/ethiopia-g7-foreign-ministers-statement-on-tigray
The Ethiopian government is still projecting that they have the situation under control, continuing the state of emergency undermines the message.

Residents are saying that the police operations in Tigray have petered out so to me, if the Ethiopian people and Ethiopian government want to work together on building trust after this, letting the state of emergency expire is most likely to be the best bet. It may also encourage more humanitarian aid which the government has pleaded for. Though if there is such human rights crimes going on, keeping the state of emergency may be a way to hide evidence but I see that as less plausible than my current thinking. Raising due to evidence of continued fighting in some areas. If it is not extended within 2 weeks of the expiration of the SoE, I'm predicting a higher chance it will expire before they can declare another one in the time between the expiration and the question close date.
increased because deadline closer and on balance not more likely to be resolved behore due date

Raising to come closer to consensus, but I don't think it's reflecting a lot of what's going on. Access to media has been granted, journalists have been freed, the government continues to deny atrocities despite UN and US pressure (terminating State of Emergency could be a political way to defy these allegations), and I have seen an Ethiopian on Twitter speaking that conditions are back to "normal" there and another Ethiopian shared an independent opinion that the leaders may actually be seeking a peace resolution. Though, on the other hand, if the government is claiming victory over the opposition forces, why is it still in an SoE? Further, the accusations of mass rape and poor conditions for women there especially make me rise my probability percentage to 50/50 at this point.
Very volatile situatiion

In early November 2020, military confrontations between federal and regional forces in Ethiopia’s Tigray region, which borders both Sudan and Eritrea, led the Government to declare a State of Emergency. Since then, and despite the announcement of an official end to military operations at the end of November, Ethiopia’s Tigray region has continued to be affected by armed clashes and insecurity. ‘OHCHR named the Ethiopian National Defence Forces, the Tigray People’s Liberation Front, Eritrean armed forces, and Amhara Regional Forces and affiliated militia as culprits.’ That suggests atrocities by all parties with no end in sight. My suggestion is that there will certainly be a state of emergency; but will this be federally imposed or by the UN (with especial concern over refugees.

It seems back in December 2020 the government called the threat defeated. The government also denied this year that ethical cleansing is going on that US claims were occurring there. There are talks to reopen schools, hospitals are getting back up to speed, there is a COVID testing effort, and there is repeated use of the word normalcy, normal, and security - which was the cause for the termination of one of the past state of emergencies. There is also a strong military presence at the border where Tigray's people fled out of. The government is urging them to return to their homes. Additionally, most SoE's do not seem to last that long. At best, this current SoE may go all the way until expiration date and will not be renewed. I suspect now is the time to start talking about any sense of renewing it. There seems to be no urgency to renew it. *@raciulo mentioned that one of their SoE's was for COVID and it only lasted 5 months, even though COVID is not a 5-month stint. Confirms my confidence that there is a greater chance of letting the Tigray SoE expire.
https://www.state.gov/atrocities-in-ethiopias-tigray-region/
The latest reports do not look rosy. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Tigray_War
There seems to be an optimistic tone through the government's social media, as conditions seem to worsen, yet there are arguments to both sides.

The book "algorithms" to live by inspired to have another go at setting the base rate for this question. https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/25666050-algorithms-to-live-by More specifically it documents the difference in forecasting approach based on the distribution of outcomes, distinguishing between normal-, powerlaw- and erlang distributed data. Whereas i previously had (by default) assumed a normal distribution, a closer inspections learned me that the duration of the conflicts quite clearly follows a PL, in which half of the conflicts last arround a year or less and about 1/6 last 3 years or longer. The intuition behind power-law forecasting is "the longer something has taken, the longer it will take still". I used a quick&dirty implementation of this, looking at what percentage of conflicts lasting > 125 days end up lasting > 189 days (using 4/11/20 and 12/5/21). This led me to a probability of 89% (compared with just 63 for the normal distribution).
Depends on extension by May 4th.

This is a case of regionalism vs. federalism. The state of emergency has resulted in humanitarian and economic crisis in the region. The emergency will have to be seen in the light of June elections. If the anti-incumbency factor has to be removed against the Prime Minister, then there has to be loosening of emergency through the following means: 1) Withdrawal of Eritrean forces 2) Allowing international humanitarian aid 3) Releasing the opposition leaders 4) Dialogue between federal government and opposition rebels

Regarding violence that included an attack on a military base and contentious regional elections, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed imposed a state of emergency in the Tigray region, which was approved by lawmakers. The Prime Minister “accused the opposition-led local government of attacking federal troops and trying to “loot” military assets” (Al Jazeera). There could be a 90% chance of this happening.

Duration of previous states of emergency in Ethiopia in the last 5 years: - October 2016/July 2017: 10 months, reason: national policy (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016-18_Ethiopian_state_of_emergency); - april 2018/june 2018: 3months, reason: national policy (https://www.cairn.info/les-chocs-du-futur--9782100779413-page-248.htm) - april 2020-august2020,5months, reason:covid (https://www.ouest-france.fr/sante/virus/coronavirus/covid-19-en-ethiopie-le-non-respect-du-port-du-masque-peut-etre-puni-de-deux-ans-de-prison-7029866)

"The federal Government military operation in Tigray Region that started on 4 November was officially declared over by the Government on 28 November after capturing the capital city, Mekelle. However, arrests of the leadership of the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) are ongoing. As a result, localized fighting and insecurity reportedly continues, with fighting reported in Enda Baguna (south of Shire), Korem and Mahbere Tsige (west of Mekelle) last week." https://reliefweb.int/report/ethiopia/ethiopia-tigray-region-humanitarian-update-situation-report-28-december-2020

The Tigray rebel forces have vowed to keep fighting, and their historical track record as regards such commitments is solid, whereas the central government cannot back-down without very high political costs.

The emergency declaration is linked to the unrest in Tigray, which is unlikely to abate any time soon, and even if it does, it is likely that the government will renew it (especially because it was originally approved unanimously).

The Ethiopian government has many challenges in addition to the recent change in government. The country is in negotiations with Sudan and Egypt regarding water rights after starting to fill the GERD earlier this summer. The U.S. has sanctioned Ethiopia and Egypt is becoming more aggressive in the negotiations. The combination of internal civil war, regional threats and the struggling economy will pressure the government to maintain domestic security.
From Mekelle they will fall back to Aksum

Ethiopian PM Abiy Ahmed has rejected African Union assistance on 20 Nov and ordered a military offensive to encircle the Tigrayan capital of Mekelle (500,000 people). The conflict does not seem likely to resolve in the short-term, particularly while military action is underway and aid restrictions to the region worsen the humanitarian situation. The current PM has already delayed elections (delay announced in June 2020 for August 2020 elections) with lawmaker approval due to COVID-19, which is one of the reasons that sparked the crisis. This provides a baseline for his continued control and influence over parliament through at least May or June 2021 (when the next election is currently estimated to be held). A transition of power would not occur immediately, so the chance of continued differences of opinion between the PM and the TPLF factions through 12 May 2021 (for this question) is rather high, and extension of the SOE is likely to follow.

This state of emergency (SOE) will still be in place on May 12, 2021, because of: - The difficulty in capturing the 12-member Tigray executive committee - The refugee and humanitarian crisis in the region

"State of emergency" looks like a popular ruling concept in this country, of which I don't know anything at all for starters and am just reading up on via wikipedia. An earlier SOE was started in oct 16 for "6 months" and ended after 10 , after parliament voted to extend.

The Ethiopian government is currently flying air strikes against Tigray region, which typically is the preparation of a larger ground campaign. Assuming this to be true, it is likely that the armed forces will quickly overwhelm the rebels in a symmetric conflict due to their superiority in arms power. This will cause many refugees to flee the region. Overall, the region is likely to experience a lot of hardships in the coming months. In order to bring stability to the region after a military victory, the Ethiopian government will likely need additional security measures in place and use them to remove any remaining rebels. This is likely not finished in the next months, so the initial 6 months period will highly likely not be shortened.
A lot will depend on how the unrest proceeds.

The current Ethiopian government feels threatened by an increasingly assertive Tigray region community, which in turn feels entitled compared to the average Ethiopian due to historic reasons. The Tigray community has no intention of backing down from their claims without a severe confrontation, so the government has no incentive to ease up on their clamp down.
first guess no research yet

The political situation here is complex as is the question. The Ethiopian government may declare a state of emergency, but Tigray will ignore it. I will assume that even though a state of emergency has been declared, Tigray probably would agree that they are not ‘under’ the state of emergency. However, given the wording of the question, the government will renew the state of emergency. Ethiopia has a federal constitution based on ethnic lines with each area having a degree of autonomy to administer their regions. Tigray has a history of being a ruling group and was instrumental of displacing a previous Marxist ruler. The current leader Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has attempted to de-federalise the country to which Tigray disagrees and held an illegal election. Abiy has refused to negotiate with the Tigray leaders until they are in custody and their weapons destroyed. Tigray has an army of 250,000 that has been described as ‘battle hardened’ that is larger than the Ethiopian army of 1652,000 (that is probably not). Tigray is not demanding separation from Ethiopia but rather to maintain its status. This does indicate the potential of a civil war that may be settled by arbitration/negotiation arbitrated by the African Union. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/11/15/rockets-fired-from-ethiopias-tigray-region-hit-eritrean-capital https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-54826875 https://www.globalfirepower.com/country-military-strength-detail.asp?country_id=ethiopia https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/05/world/africa/ethiopia-war-tigray.html https://www.npr.org/2020/11/13/934241830/what-to-know-about-ethiopias-tigray-conflict https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-54932333

States of emergency are quite rare in Ethiopia as the one in 2016 was the first in 25 years. In that crisis the government ruled to tack on another 4 months of the state of emergency. Under the current prime minister he imposed a state of emergency due to covid that lasted 5 months although I could not find if it was extended or not. The essence of the question is whether the government will lengthen the state of emergency after it runs out on May 4th 2021. Judging by recent history and the insistence of the Tigray group (who are firing rockets at nearby Eritrea) I assume that the fighting will be ongoing by May. However the question is whether the country will still be under a state of emergency. I think they will be, but I could also see a situation where the fighting continues but Ahmed does not want the official label of state of emergency especially with elections sometime in 2021. Ahmed has already won a nobel peace prize and will I imagine be eager to quickly end this conflict, I just do not think that the Tigrey will go down quietly or quickly. I believe that the gov will vote to renew the state of emergency and I am giving it a 65% chance of happening, but I will also be watching the fighting and Ahmed's words to update the forecast.
Six months State of Emergency seems a tall ask given the way things are escalating

“Tigrayans may only make up 6% of Ethiopia’s 110 million population, but the TPLF dominated Ethiopia’s military and government for much of the past three decades, until Abiy took office in 2018“ (https://time.com/5910962/abiy-ahmed-ethiopia-conflict/ ) at which point he acted to disenfranchise them creating a classic scenario for a brewing civil war. This was already brewing with Ahmed in power Nobel peace prize or not. Even if they break away they wont be recognized by Ethiopia so we’re really looking at a question of how draconian will the suppression be...and will Ethiopia devolve into chaos.
The area will want to break away and want to self Govern, this may well come in the near future as calls for an independent State

There will still be armed conflict in May unless the PM Ahmed is taken out of office. Tigray has the best forces and will not back down. The central government at this point must try to see Tigray fall inline. That may take a long time or Tigray may outlast the PM.
